Bribe
By giving certain politicians money, you can improve your relations with the faction. Only for the Families.
Luxury Bribe
By giving certain politicians Luxury Resources, you can improve your relations with the faction.
Praise
Use your Influence to flatter key politicians, which will improve your relations with the faction.
Assimilate
Bring the minor civilization into your empire and gain its traits.
First Contact
They don't know you yet. Why don't you come and shake appendages with them?
Declare War
Start a war (and set relation points to 0)
Cease Fire
Stop the war, move to a neutral non-friendly status
Protectorate
Bring the Minor Civilization into your empire as a protectorate
Brainwash
Through persuasion and propaganda, make the Minor Civilization your ally and receive their faction trait.
Selective Migration
Trigger the migration of a unit of population from the Minor Civilization's system to the closest system you own.
Collect Essence Tribute
Extract the vital Essence out of a unit of population from this Minor Civilization's system. +100 [lifeforceColored]
Train Foreign Corps
Using a unit of population from this Minor Civilization's system, train a task force you will be able to use as mercenaries.
Development Grants
Fund the development of this Minor Civilization's system, temporarily increasing its yields and giving you access to its faction trait
Attack
Attack strongest enemy fleet in orbit (from list of empires if applicable)
Implant Beacon
Will summon a Vine from an adjacent "entwined" System. The Vineship must stay in position until the Vine reaches the System.
Colonize
Creates an Outpost on the System this fleet is orbiting
Anchor/Withdraw Ark
Anchors or withdraws the Ark from the System
Retrofit Ships
Update the Ships to their latest Ship Design
Harvest Essence
Harvest this vital energy from a System using Essence-gathering modules. Food and growth will be transferred from the target system to your ship.
Drop Tribute
You can drop the resources your ships have collected on a nearby System.
Sleep
Remain idle on this System until an enemy enters it or a probe is built
Skip turn
Remain idle on this System until an enemy enters or the turn ends
Auto-explore
Move automatically to the closest unexplored destination
Start Expedition
Search for Curiosities in this System and gain potential rewards or information
Invade
Execute a Ground Invasion of the System and spare its Population.
Execute an assault on the Ark using ground forces. If successful, the Ark will be destroyed and stay as a Wreck on this system. You will capture any planet currently exploited by the Ark.
Guard

Guard the System - Stops enemy ships for 1 turn when entering orbit - Blockades opponents' Systems, lowering their Influence, Dust and Science production and negating production of Luxury and Strategic Resources
This fleet steals {0} per turn from enemy Trade Routes passing through this Node
Reclaim Ark
Restore the Ark that has been destroyed on this node. This will take {0} [turn]
You are currently restoring an Ark on this node. If your fleet is not interrupted in the next {0} [turn] you will gain control of the Ark.
+ retrofit
Ship retrofit
Launch Probes
Launch probes in order to explore the vicinity of this star system
Industrialist Propaganda
Scientist Propaganda
Pacifist Propaganda
Ecologist Propaganda
Religious Propaganda
Militarist Propaganda
Neutral Propaganda
Evacuate System
Forcibly remove the minor civilization's presence from the System
Assist
Assimilate the minor civilization by providing assistance with a problem.
Privateer
Turn this fleet into a privateer, shown as pirate for other factions. Requires all ships to be Mercenaries (bought on the marketplace)
There is at least one privateer fleet of your Empire among these fleets, but to other factions they appear as a pirate fleet.
Destroy Planet
Use your mass destruction weapon to destroy a planet of this system.
Shift Back
Reverse time for the fleet, and shift it back to the last node it visited.

Content

Anarchy
Your government is in transition. Be it bureaucratic evolution or popular revolution, it's a time of great turmoil that leads to empire-wide inefficiency. No laws can be enacted.
The Unstable Anarchy of {0}
Anarchy has little in the way of processes…
Anarchy is not a practical situation for managing laws.
Democracy
A Democracy gives power to the people. Each system votes according to their ideology, creating a supposedly fair representation in the Senate.
The Democratic Union of {0}
- Representatives scale with Population - Actions to influence elections are expensive
- Democracies increase the number of Active Laws slots available
Dictatorship
A system where the monarch, or tyrant, is in absolute power. Leaves space only for a single chosen ideology, regardless of the population's desires.
The {0} Dominion
- Dictators can impose their desired political ideology on their Populations - However, the further this ideology from the Population's natural inclinations, the bigger the friction
- Dictators can impose a single Law associated with their chosen political ideology at no Influence cost
Autocracy
A system where the monarch, or tyrant, is in absolute power. Leaves space only for a single chosen ideology, regardless of the population's desires
The {0} Dominion

- Dictators can impose their desired political ideology on their Populations - Only the Major population can vote - However, the further this ideology is from the Population's natural inclinations, the greater the friction
- Dictators can impose a single Law associated with their chosen political ideology at no Influence cost
Federation

A Federation does not waste time on individual populations' desires; rather they gather the governors of systems to decide the political fate of the empire. Of course, influential governors carry more weight in the outcome . . .
The Federated Systems of {0}
- Representatives scale with the System level - Actions to influence elections are powerful
- No special effects
Republic
A Republic is less direct than a Democracy, dividing populations in groups that share an ideology. The intention, however, stays the same.
The {0} Galactic Republic
- Representatives scale with Population - Actions have a normal cost and are diversified
'- No special effects
Aggressive
Plays that emphasize inflicting higher damage.
Defensive
Plays that emphasize reducing damage taken.
Post Battle
Plays that concentrate on acquiring post-battle bonuses.
Shield Wall
Tighten ranks and enhance armor to minimize short range damage taken
Prudent Positions
Reduces damage across flotillas to minimize ship loss
Power to Shields
Used to improve defenses against energy weapons at the cost of attack power.
Hard Target
Increases long range defenses; used to keep distance in battle
Turtle
Used to improve ship hull plating defenses against projectile weapons
Evasive Maneuvers
Improves defense at long range; used to close with enemy
Plasma Distortion
Increases energy penetration for everyone; best against an opponent without energy weapons but with energy defense
Bigger is Better
Increases accuracy based on ship size; used against opponents with large ships
Barrage Fire
Increases damage based on number of enemy ships; used against swarm attacks
Gravity Distortion
Increases projectile penetration for everyone; best against opponents without projectile weapons but with projectile defenses.
Gravity Distortion 2
Improved version of Gravity Distortion; best against opponents without projectile weapons but with projectile defenses.
Team Spirit
Improves effects of morale bonus which increases your damage when enemy has fewer active flotillas.
Soft Targets
Improves targeting of civilian ships; used to destroy colonization / trade ships.
Revive and Rebuild
Recycles ships if fleet not destroyed; used in desperate situations.
Post-Op Analysis
Increases experience gained from battles and improves fleet power
Take Trophies
Recycles enemy ships; used when enemy casualties will be high.
Repair and Recover
Repairs empire ships after the battle
Hopeless
Morale bonus (when a side has more active flotillas) becomes a penalty (can effect either side); use it against a fleet with many ships or if you plan to group your ships into a single flotilla
Unlucky Arms
No critical bonuses in battle (defense effects are always applied); use it against a fleet that inflicts a lot of critical hits
Get Lucky
Critical hits get a damage bonus; use it if your ships are equipped with weapons that give a high chance of critical hits
Influential
Earn Influence based on destroyed ships; use it if you think you will destroy ships and want to receive Influence after the battle
Science from Scrap
Earn Science based on destroyed ships; use it if you think you will destroy ships and want to receive Science after the battle
Irradiation
Kill additional Manpower per successful hit with energy weapons; use it to kill the opponent's Manpower if you have energy weapons
Shrapnel Munitions
Kill additional Manpower per successful hit with projectile weapons; use it to kill the opponent's Manpower if you have projectile weapons
Lifepods Away!
Part of the Manpower killed returns to the empire stock; use it against a fleet that kills Manpower to save some and return them to the empire
Needs of the Many
Sacrifice Manpower to get more power for this battle; use it if your ships have extra Manpower to get a bonus for this battle
Radiation Shield
Shields protect Manpower; use it if you have Shields and want to protect your Manpower
Anti-Shrapnel Hull
Hull plating protects Manpower; use it if you have Plating defenses and want to protect your Manpower
Grim Recycling
Repair after battle proportionally to the number of ships lost; use it if you think you will suffer heavy losses and want to repair the survivors
Emergency Battery
Shield recharge (between phases); use it if your Shields can't resist the opponent's (mostly energy) weapons
The Fewer the Proud
Get a fleet damage boost each time an allied ship is destroyed; use it if you think you will suffer heavy losses or if you have plenty of ships
En Passant
Have a movement point after the battle; use it to be able to travel after the battle.
Full Reserves
Have an action point after the battle but reduced power; use it to be able to fight again with this fleet during this turn
By Any Means
Sacrifice Influence to get power bonus; use it if you have available Influence to get a damage bonus
Temporal Drag
Increase cooldown for all ships (less damage will be done by both sides); use it to reduce the overall damage done in the battle and protect your ships
Diplomatic Immunity
Increases defenses of the 0 [offensiveMilitaryPower] ships for both sides; use it to protect your unarmed (civilian) ships
Smart Survivors
Gain XP per lost Command Point (will be divided between surviving ships); use it if you think you will suffer heavy losses in order to level up the survivors
Sheredyn Slugs
Better Hull plating penetration for projectile weapons; use it if you have projectile weapons to improve their efficiency against Hull Plating
Easy Targets
Defense penalty per Command Point for both sides; use it if you have small ships to help you destroy big ships
Collateral Damage
A percentage of the damage applied is spread on the other ships of the flotilla; use it against flotillas with a lot of small ships or against a grouped fleet
BRF-JSIM Creatives Ltd

With a vast pool of creative talent in every conceivable commercial niche from antique architecture to augmented-reality advertising, BRF-JSIM Creatives sends freelancers across the galaxy. No job too self-indulgent!
Avalon Industries LLP

The origin of the name has been lost to the mists of time, but nevertheless Avalon has forged a reputation for industrial machinery of peerless quality. From vast terraforming equipment to starship engines, this company's products are rarely bettered. Their motto? Avalon works.
Andromeda Corporation

The words logistics, finance, and consulting often crop up, but nobody is sure what the Andromeda Corporation do exactly. What is clear, however, is that their interests across the galaxy bring in huge profits.
InterStar Group

A vast communications firm, InterStar Group gained infamy for a record-breaking comms bill for a short call between the constellations of Cetus and Aries a few years back. When the billed customer disputed the charges, InterStar's lawyers made short work of the claim, and in fact went on to bankrupt the claimant's entire world.
Polaris Incorporated
A highly competent sci-tech conglomerate, Polaris specializes in stellar-related technologies from coronal-mass ejection monitoring to photosphere extreme sports equipment to deep space solar energy.
AstroBrands Logistics

When businesses are heading south, there are no better companies for turning around one's fortunes than AstroBrands Logistics. Experts in markets of diverse cultures and languages, AstroBrands can helpfully point out, for example, if the translation of your company tagline is saying something deeply offensive about the mothers of Kalgeros individuals.
Meosian Assets Group

Creators of mega-sized entertainment complexes that can span entire moons, Meosian Assets Group is the company behind brands which send paroxysms of joy through the young, and the fear of bankruptcy through their parents. Rumored to have interests in the swiftly-growing field of debt collection with their subsidiary company Relentless Pursuits.
Takagake Industrial

A producer of alloys and metals of unparalleled quality, Takagake Industrial is often found on new worlds or experimental projects where any flaws in the materials could prove fatal. A spin-off company manufactures bespoke ceremonial blades, swords, and other historical weaponry employed on battlefields of the past.
Ursa Major Shipping

We Ship Anything, Anywhere: that's the bold motto of Ursa Major Shipping, who specialize in the transportation of substances, and even lifeforms, that are considered too dangerous or too illegal for other operators. Naturally their legal team is first-rate.
Deep Space Holdings

By bypassing local laws that are applicable in-system, Deep Space Holdings have made a name for themselves in providing commercial services at the edges of solar systems where a much murkier legal framework exists. It shouldn't surprise anyone that one of their most profitable offshoots is in the security sector.

Intimidate Citizens
Provides a [green]strong penalty#REVERT# to the competitors. Ideal if the chosen party is not one of the favorites.
Reinforced intimidation on Citizens
Provides a [green]very strong penalty#REVERT# to the competitors. Ideal if the chosen party is not one of the favorites.
Imperial Support
Provides a [green]strong boost#REVERT# to the selected political party. Ideal if the chosen party is already well supported.
Reinforced Imperial Support
Provides a [green]very strong boost#REVERT# to the selected political party. Ideal if the chosen party is already well supported.
Primary Elections
Provides a [green]strong boost#REVERT# to the selected political party. Ideal if the chosen party is already well supported.
Efficient Primary Elections
Provides a [green] very strong boost#REVERT# to the selected political party. Ideal if the chosen party is already well supported.
Lobbying
Provides a [green]strong penalty#REVERT# to the competitors. Ideal if the chosen party is not one of the favorites.
Strong-arm Lobbying
Provides a [green]very strong penalty#REVERT# to the competitors. Ideal if the chosen party is not one of the favorites.
Hekim

The Sophons evolved on Hekim, a rocky world orbiting a blue star. As their sun produced relatively high radiation, their rate of mutation and evolution was unusually rapid. Though their world is cold, numerous volcanic fissures and vents created networks of warm spots, oases, and habitable cave systems which allowed the Sophons to indulge themselves in the study of biology and geology from early in their history. With natural energy sources leaving the atmosphere clear, their eyes soon turn to the study of the stars . . .
Husk

Built by the Virtual Endless during the Dust Wars as weapons, the Cravers successfully wiped many planets and stations clean of the Concretes. Once their usefulness was over, however, the Endless shut down the factories and abandoned the Cravers, dumping the remaining troops on Husk, a random planet, and bombing it back to the Stone Age. Grim and resolute the Cravers survived and evolved, using makeshift and stolen technology to scrabble their way back to the stars.
Jenes

Jenes, an atoll planet full of tropical islands and tropical storms, is the home of the Lumeris civilization and the home base of the Lumeris Families that rule it from behind the scenes. Their oceanic environment necessitated the ability to adapt to the water, yet the need to create fire and build advanced technologies drove them to the land. From there they are now challenging the heavens themselves, bringing their unique style of economic development to an unsuspecting galaxy.
Koyasil

An ancient world, its origin lost to the mists of time, Koyasil's entire landmass is now one vast, primeval forest. How long ago the Unfallen rose from the gloomy, silent woodlands is uncertain, but most historians who have studied the species of the galaxy place them as one of the oldest. In the depths of the forest, a sense of timelessness reigns supreme, and it is said a fallen tree will lay undisturbed for millennia, its very fabric becoming another layer of the forest. The Unfallen strive for little, content in their ageless world, but the stirrings of younger races across the galaxy has awoken something in Koyasil . . . something ancient, mysterious, and powerful.
Tchinomy

The home planet of the Vodyani was a poor yet temperate world, and the fragility of its environment meant it was soon depleted. As a result the Vodyani were driven into space by necessity, and already have a long history as a ship-bound people. Though their civilization is now tied to their Arks, their planet of origin remains a powerful symbol both as a lesson in ecology and as a memory of the weak and grotesque forms they had before Virtual technology allowed them to evolve beyond that.
Tor

The Endless society developed on this large, cool planet, orbiting a star that they called Prime. Though it is the birthplace of this culture that dominated the galaxy for centuries, they were forced to depart when over-exploitation destabilized the core and crust, triggering seismic changes. Though it is a treasure of artifacts and holds a near-mystical reputation, its history is one of sorrow.
Kyros

Kyros, when discovered, was a planet whose environment was so welcoming that it was taken by many pre-Dust Endless sects as their promised paradise. Unfortunately, conflict and strife exploded over its care and exploitation, and a "grey goo" nanobot plague was unleashed as a suicidal Doomsday weapon that destroyed the biosphere. It exists today only as a memorial and object lesson.
Auriga

This garden planet was used as a biological laboratory by the Concrete Endless, with myriad experiments run on both native and alien life forms. A site of major conflict during the Dust Wars, the environment degraded and the surface of the planet was eventually covered in ice. While there are rumors and expeditions that claim to have uncovered miraculous ruins and the vestiges of great empires, today Auriga is an icy tomb.
Bilgeli

A hospitable--if dry--planet, rich in natural resources, Bilgeli served as the base for the Endless research stations that were built in its orbit. One of them in particular, Letum, has a fairly legitimate claim as being the first place in Endless history where the science of virtualization was perfected. For better or for worse, this fact has given it an important role in the mythos of the Endless civilization.
Raia

The first Mezari starships arrived millennia ago, landing on a green, virginal--and empty--planet of breathtaking, fecund wildernesses. Today, Raia proudly shows its pioneering, frontier past as it tamed the wild lands and storm-wracked seas, its landmasses now brimming with mighty industrial swathes and vast urban powerhouses. On the oceans stand huge mining platforms, Raia's riches now the United Empire's riches. Above, half-built starship yards orbit the conquered world, as the Empire prepares to take its glorious civilization to the rest of the galaxy.
Horatio Prime

Horatio Prime is a world that in most other factions would serve as the vacation planet. Dry, warm, breezy, and beautiful, it is clear from the extensive Endless ruins that more than one spacefaring race has selected it as a preferred destination. Its current infrastructure projects tend to vary with Horatio’s tastes; some buildings blend seamlessly with the landscape while others are garish and metallic statements of architectural extravagance.
Vanguard

Upon arrival in the galaxy, the Riftborn settled on a snow-covered world that they named Vanguard. Like the rest of the universe they find themselves in, they have little love for the planet, yet in its pristine, white snowfields they find an echo of their own universe, Coroz. Less a home, and more a staging ground for further explorations, the Riftborn inhabit a small corner of the world with order and vigor.
Sahar

Though Sahar at first appears to be just another dry planet, devoid of anything other than the simplest of life forms, faint geometric patterns that beg to be investigated seem to be etched on its surface. Initial scans indicate that surface ruins do not appear to be related to these patterns. There is clearly a story here of some form of civilization, but nothing remains that can easily be documented from orbit. Only excavation and exploration might potentially reveal what may once have existed.
Sykagoja

This lushly forested world was once a major center of the Endless. Oddly, it was a center both of medical research and of entertainment, for it was here that the avian race called the Hissho were first modified to be more effective warriors, and then trained to provide bloodsport spectacles for bored audiences. The wealth brought by the broadcasts was rolled back into the research facilities and some to the Hissho themselves. Who knows how long this media symbiosis might have gone on, had a Virtual attack not destroyed the infrastructure and cut the Hissho free to forge their own destiny.
Veil

From orbit this planet is visually uninteresting. Silent and undeveloped, it turns beneath the glare of an indifferent star. History and legend claim it is one of the great centers of Virtual study, however, and the seat of the sub-faction commonly known as the Cabal of Pure Thought. Should these tales be true, the planet would be rich with power generation centers, networks, and a planet-wide infrastructure of super-conducting cables. Until there is a way to render these visible, however, the planet merely appears as it is.
Teonha

The origin planet of the strange race known as the Bhagaba, who are a distributed artificial intelligence whose calculations are done by the random movement of rocks, stones, and even grains of sand on this atoll planet. The warming and cooling of natural ocean currents coupled with tidal shifts and weather turns these elements into a living series of gates and arrays; this in turns transforms the entirety of the planet into a giant computer capable of reason and reflection. The very existence of this planet has caused heated arguments among philosophers and clerics of all stripes, as it is clearly either the work of a supreme being or the irrefutable evidence that one cannot exist.
MU3R74

From space the planet seems typical of many an advanced civilization's--large-scale infrastructure, dense urban/industrial areas, cultivated wildernesses--except for one anomaly: the complete absence of a comms spectrum at any wavelengths. Planetside, the truth becomes shockingly clear. MU3R74 is a ghost world, terraformed for future inhabitants who never arrived. The corroding shells of Sowers, the self-replicating robotic workers tasked with making planets habitable for the Virtual Endless, litter the world. What befell the Sowers is unclear. Machine plague? Mass suicide? Whatever it is, the outcome looks like a silent apocalypse.
Chiark

Whoever shaped this world into its present form is lost to the sands of time, but it is clear they possessed a mastery of time and space--and games. The whole world is, in fact, the galaxy's most complex game, and players can spend whole lifetimes attempting to master its intricacies. Shrouded in thick mists from the outside, players who "enter" the game find themselves in something akin to a vast living simulation and must rely on all their wits and knowledge to progress. What purpose the game serves is unknown, and whether anybody has ever won is arguable, but what is certain is that the world attracts the galaxy's best minds.
Harrow

Destroyed in some ancient cataclysm of unknown providence, today all that remains of the original planet is a vast archipelago of stony islands floating in the void of space. Some of these remnants are no bigger than a rock, while others span thousands of klicks, generating their own gravitational fields. All carry whispers of their past. Still held captive by the local star, with each passing millennia these islands spread a little further apart destined to one day appear to be an ordinary asteroid belt, but as long as the fabled Academy remains here, Harrow will never be considered ordinary.
Open Borders
This means that the empires open their borders to each other. This will allow ships to move freely through the Systems of both empires and increase Trade and Science.
Close Borders
This means that the empires close their borders to each other. Ships will no longer be able to move freely through the other empire's Systems. Trade and Science will decrease.
Peace
This means that the empires would be at Peace. All hostilities anywhere on the galactic map will cease, and more advanced diplomatic negotiations will be possible.
Force Peace
This puts the empires into a status of Peace. All hostilities anywhere on the galactic map will cease, and more advanced diplomatic negotiations will be possible.
Truce
This means that the empires would enter a Truce. All hostilities anywhere on the galactic map cease, borders will be closed, and declaring war will be more expensive for a while.
Cold War
This means that the empires would be at Cold War. Ships of the other empire may be attacked on neutral territory or if they invade your territory without declaring War.
War
This means that the empires would be at War. This is automatic if ships are attacked inside their home Systems. No treaty is possible except Truce from this status.
Alliance

This means that the empires would join an Alliance. Alliances automatically share galactic map and ship vision data. If there is a Close Borders treaty it is automatically nullified. Advanced diplomatic negotiations are possible.
Technology Transfer
You propose that there is a transfer of scientific knowledge.
Resource Exchange
You propose to trade valuable resources.
Colony Trade
You discuss the exchange of a Colony with another empire.
Outpost Cession
You discuss the exchange of an Outpost with another empire.
Request Alliance
This is a request to enter into Alliance with another empire. This will modify your victory conditions.
Leave Alliance
This is a request to leave their existing Alliance.
Propose Alliance
This is a request to create an Alliance with another empire.
Propose Peace
This is a request to sign a Peace treaty with another empire.
Declare War
This is a statement that you are going to war with another empire.
Declare War
This is a statement that you are going to war on another empire.
Vision Sharing
This is a request to share the Ship, System and Probe Vision with another empire (you will see what they see on the galaxy view).
Cancel Vision Sharing
This is a unilateral declaration to stop a Vision Sharing agreement with another empire.
Map Sharing
This is a request to share the known galactic map with another empire.
Trade Agreement

If signed, a Trade Agreement will trace routes between all your HQs and the other player's Subsidiaries, and vice versa. Trade Routes cannot cross enemy systems and can be interrupted by war, blockades, etc.
Cancel Trade Agreement
This is a unilateral declaration to stop a Trade Agreement with another empire.
Science Agreement
Both you and the other player gain an incremental boost to your research; the longer the Science agreement lasts, the better the boost.
Cancel Science Agreement
This is a unilateral declaration to stop a Science Agreement with another empire.
Pressure Reduction
This is a proposal to remove the diplomatic and territorial pressure on another empire in exchange for something.
Pressure Cessation
This is a demand to remove the diplomatic and territorial pressure on another empire in exchange for something.
Introduce Yourself
This is to present yourself to another empire who you have discovered, but who themselves are currently unaware of you. It will unlock new diplomatic options.
Break Peace Treaty with {0}
This is to force this empire to break their existing Peace with another empire.
Break Science Agreement with {0}
This is to force this empire to break their existing Science Agreement with another empire.
Break Trade Agreement with {0}
This is to force this empire to break their existing Trade Agreement with another empire.
Bureaucratic obstacles
Through a deluge of formal diplomatic requests and actions, you manage to clutter diplomatic channels with this empire and increase your pressure on him.
Score Victory
Military Victory
Terraform To Arctic

While cold is amply available in the 0 Kelvin vacuum of space, the process of applying the correct amount of cold while hydrating a planet is not a simple operation. Atmospheric engineering and an advanced knowledge of water chemistry is needed to complete the process successfully.
Terraform To Desert

Though the climate may be hostile, a desert planet can be rich in valuable resources. "Upgrading" from an even less hospitable planet is still a major task, requiring the creation of atmosphere, some basic level of soils and hydration, and even simple life forms.
Terraform To Snow

Arbitrarily differentiated from "Arctic" by a galactic index indicating probability and richness of native life, terraforming to Snow is primarily a question of generating greater seasonal fluctuation and seeding the planet with simple life forms adapted to the cold, wet environment.
Terraform To Steppes

Though cool and dry, Steppes planets can support plant and animal life, even in massive forms like auroch or wolf. Warming the planet through manipulation of the atmosphere is the other key change that needs to be successfully handled by terraforming.
Terraform To Savannah

Relatively dry and relatively warm, Savannah planets can nevertheless support a wide variety of plant and animal life. Seeding these life forms and regulating the atmosphere to an acceptable level are the key changes required to terraform.
Terraform To Arid

Typically done to elevate a less hospitable planet type to Arid, this project requires the creation of viable soils and a functioning, if relatively dry, atmosphere. It is still an enormous investment in energy, raw materials, and time.
Terraform To Boreal

Teeming with animal life and vegetation in spite of its relative cold, terraformation into a Boreal-type planet requires introduction of a wide range of species and a soil sufficiently rich to serve as the base of the ecosystem.
Terraform To Jungle

Changing any planet type into a world as rich and vibrant as a jungle requires time, dedication, and extremely sophisticated bioengineering. A masterpiece of applied genetics, artificial evolution, and resource utilization, this transformation is only available to the most advanced societies.
Terraform To Monsoon

Primarily famous for the dampness of the atmosphere and the relatively fierce storms, Monsoon-type planets require terraforming that involves hydration on a massive scale as well as balanced temperatures.
Terraform To Terran

Rich and varied, a Terran-class planet is one of the most viable and valuable planet types in the universe. Transforming another planet into this type is necessarily an expensive and scientifically complex task. But, like most things in life, it wouldn't be interesting if it were too easy.
Terraform To Ocean

Water. An atom of oxygen bound to two simple hydrogens; something minimal and simple but necessary on the scale of a few trillion cubic kilometers to create an ocean world. While the result is a planet potentially wealthy in life and resources, it is not a project for the faint of heart.
Terraform To Atoll

Picturesque due to the islands and sea, these planets require a relatively rich marine environment and a relatively simple land environment. Terraforming therefore revolves around temperature, ocean life, and undersea mountains.
Terraform To Forest

Moisture and in particular a deep and rich soil base are required for these terraformation efforts. A temperate atmosphere and relatively high precipitation are not enough if the dirt itself lacks the nutrients.
Terraform To Lava

Through the use of effective (if clumsy) streams of gravitons, planetary cores can be liquefied and the basics of plate tectonics imposed on a planetoid. This effectively turns the planetary body into a seething cauldron that creates high-value minerals; it may somewhat reduce its value for tourism.
Terraform To Ash

Terraforming a planet into ash requires imitating the affect of the millennia of volcanic activity required to deposit the layers of ash. Typically space debris and fusion heat are required to produce the necessary effect.
Terraform To Barren
A planet described as "barren" is generally devoid of air, water, and anything else that makes it habitable. Though this sounds unpleasant, certain peoples find these planets ideal for their needs.
Terraform To Ice

The delicate issue with this terraformation is to remove enough atmosphere to drop the temperature without losing the moisture. When this is achieved, however, life on a chilly, lifeless ball is possible.
Terraform To Toxic

Sterilization of a living planet is a fairly direct process; radiation and poisons are both easy to come by and simple to administer. Before you start, however, be sure that the end product is really what you want.
Terraform To Tundra

Terraforming a planet into a Tundra-type requires sophisticated manipulation of temperature and humidity on a planetary scale. This requires precise thermodynamic control and a great deal of energy, neither of which would be possible without the use of exotic matter.
Terraform To Mediterranean
Though rich in water, these planets are dry and hot. Terraforming efforts target atmospheric temperatures that are consistently high and soil that is not necessarily very rich.
Terraform To Forest

This is an epic effort, to take a Barren planet and give it the soil, atmosphere, water, and weather systems to make plant life thrive. On top of that, tree species must be discovered or engineered that can survive in this newly generated environment.
Terraform To Forest

While there is some water, there is still a great deal of work to take an Arctic planet and transform it into a Forest. Planetary warming, soil bacteria, and the life forms of a rich biosphere all have to be brought to this hostile terrain.
Terraform To Forest
The major challenges in this conversion are temperature and biodiversity. Water at least is plentiful, though to change it from permanent frost to rain is still a non-negligible effort.
Terraform To Forest

The advantage of a Lava planet is that it may have a base of cooled magma that could potentially provide rich soil. It is still a difficult uphill battle to stabilize the crust, cool and filter the atmosphere, and generate enough water to support a planet-wide forest.
Terraform To Forest
Though there is a potential soil base from the Ash, the massive challenge of hydrating and cooling the planet enough to maintain a hydrological cycle make this project a difficult challenge.
Terraform To Forest

Less difficult than other possible starting points, this terraformation project nevertheless faces the challenge of hydrating and cooling the planet, as well as adapting native species to live in an arboreal environment--or replacing them and starting all over with the plant/animal ecosphere.
Rejuvenators
Defenders
